text.p: True or False: No linear transformation [mathjaxinline]T: \mathbb R^6 \rightarrow \mathbb R^8[/mathjaxinline] can be onto.
True or False: Every linear transformation [mathjaxinline]T: \mathbb R^8 \rightarrow \mathbb R^6[/mathjaxinline] must be onto.

solution.font:
Suppose [mathjaxinline]T: \mathbb R^6 \rightarrow \mathbb R^8[/mathjaxinline] is a linear transformation with standard matrix [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline]. Then [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] is onto if and only if the columns of [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] span [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^8[/mathjaxinline]. But, [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] is a [mathjaxinline]8\times 6[/mathjaxinline] matrix, and thus cannnot span [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^8[/mathjaxinline] (to see this, note that if we row reduce [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline], it can have at most 6 pivots).
Next, suppose that [mathjaxinline]T: \mathbb R^8 \rightarrow \mathbb R^6[/mathjaxinline] is a linear transformation with standard matrix [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline]. Then [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] is a [mathjaxinline]6\times 8[/mathjaxinline] matrix. It may be the case that [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] row reduces to have strictly less than 6 pivots, and thus, the columns span a proper subspace of [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^6[/mathjaxinline]. In this case, [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] would not be onto.
